table_columns.name: reference_datetime
table_columns.description: ISO 8601(ISO 2019)datetime the forecast starts from (a.k.a. issue time); Only needed if more than one reference_datetime is stored in asingle file. Forecast lead time is thus datetime-reference_datetime. Ina hindcast the reference_datetimewill be earlierthan the time thehindcast was actually produced (seepubDatein Section3). Datetimesare allowed to be earlier than thereference_datetimeif areanalysis/reforecast is run before the start of the forecast period. Thisvariable was calledstart_timebefore v0.5 of theEFI standard.

table_columns.name: site_id
table_columns.description: For forecasts that are not on a spatial grid, use of a site dimension thatmaps to a more detailed geometry (points, polygons, etc.) is allowable.In general this would be documented in the external metadata (e.g., alook-up table that provides lon and lat); however in netCDF this couldbe handled by the CF Discrete Sampling Geometry data model.

table_columns.name: datetime
table_columns.description: ISO 8601(ISO 2019)datetime being predicted; follows CF conventionhttp://cfconventions.org/cf-conventions/cf-conventions.html#time-coordinate. This variable was called time before v0.5of the EFIconvention.For time-integrated variables (e.g., cumulative net primary productivity), one should specify thestart_datetimeandend_datetimeas two variables, instead of the singledatetime.If this is not providedthedatetimeis assumed to be the MIDPOINT of theintegrationperiod.

table_columns.name: family
table_columns.description: For ensembles: “ensemble.” Default value if unspecifiedFor probability distributions: Name of the statistical distributionassociated with the reported statistics. The “sample” distribution issynonymous with “ensemble.”For summary statistics: “summary.”If this dimension does not vary, it is permissible to specifyfamilyas avariable attribute if the file format being used supports this (e.g.,netCDF).

table_columns.name: mean
table_columns.description: mean forecast prediction for all ensemble members

table_columns.name: median
table_columns.description: median forecast prediction for all ensemble members

table_columns.name: sd
table_columns.description: standard deviation of all enemble member forecasts

table_columns.name: quantile97.5
table_columns.description: upper 97.5 percentile value of ensemble member forecasts

table_columns.name: quantile02.5
table_columns.description: upper 2.5 percentile value of ensemble member forecasts

table_columns.name: quantile90
table_columns.description: upper 90 percentile value of ensemble member forecasts

table_columns.name: quantile10
table_columns.description: upper 10 percentile value of ensemble member forecasts

table_columns.name: model_id
table_columns.description: unique identifier for the model used in the forecast

table_columns.name: date
table_columns.description: ISO 8601(ISO 2019)datetime being predicted; follows CF conventionhttp://cfconventions.org/cf-conventions/cf-conventions.html#time-coordinate. This variable was called time before v0.5of the EFIconvention.For time-integrated variables (e.g., cumulative net primary productivity), one should specify thestart_datetimeandend_datetimeas two variables, instead of the singledatetime.If this is not providedthedatetimeis assumed to be the MIDPOINT of theintegrationperiod.

publications.citation: Thomas, R.Q., C. Boettiger, C.C. Carey, M.C. Dietze, L.R. Johnson, M.A. Kenney, J.S. Mclachlan, J.A. Peters, E.R. Sokol, J.F. Weltzin, A. Willson, W.M. Woelmer, and Challenge Contributors. The NEON Ecological Forecasting Challenge. Accepted at Frontiers in Ecology and Environment. Pre-print
